text: [Music]
[Music]
hello i'm pravanjan a cloud support
engineer here at the aws office in
seattle today i'm going to show you how
users can test connection to an amazon
elastic cache radish or memcached
cluster using a client such as ready cli
or telnet from a linux based client
let's get started amazon elastic cache
currently supports two different
in-memory key value engines
radish and memcaci you can choose the
engine you prefer when launching an
elastic gas cluster
let's begin with trellis cluster
elastics supports both customer disabled
and custom mode enabled radius clusters
to test a connection to these clusters
you can use the ready cli utility the
latest version of latest cli
also support ssl and tls for connecting
encryption and authentication enabled
clusters download and compile ready cli
utility on the amazon elastic compute
cloud instance that you are making
connection from for instruction on how
to connect to an amazon ec2 instance
see the tutorial documentation link in
the associated knowledge center article
i'm going to show you an example that
uses an ec2 instance running amazon
linux 2. you can also install ready cli
on other linux distributions as well see
the respective os documentation for
information on how to do this here are
the steps to install our hcli on amazon
linux 2.
now i'm going to connect to a custom
mode disabled unencrypted cluster
copy the redis cluster endpoint
from the elastic cache dashboard of your
cluster
now run the ready cli command to connect
to the cluster after you are connected
you will see a prompt that looks like
this
now you can use redis commands to test
that you have set up redis correctly
similarly you can connect to a cluster
mode enabled unencrypted cluster run the
ready cli command note i'm using this
cluster mode enabled command to avoid
ask and move errors
now i'm running tradis commands at the
prompt
next i'm going to connect to an
encryption and authentication enabled
cluster the following example connects
to an encryption and authentication
enabled encrypted cluster
the following example connects to a
cluster that has only encryption enabled
after you connect to the cluster you can
run redis command as shown in the
earlier examples for unencrypted
clusters to connect to a memcache
cluster use the telnet utility install
the telnet utility on the ec2 instance
that you are testing a connection from
use the following command to connect to
the endpoint replace this endpoint with
the endpoint of your node the output
looks similar to the following
you are now connected to a node you can
run mksd commands as shown in the
following examples
thanks for watching and happy cloud
computing from all of us here at aws
[Music]
you
